What I mean is the band pruning seems too restrictive.  Suppose a CPPN sub=
strate is being pruned for a Go game board evaluator.  If ideally the weigh=
ts along the board edge should be expressed they will be removed by band pr=
uning. Am I missing something?

Tony 
 
--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken" =
<kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> Hi Tony, I believe the issue there is with =
the definition of a "band":
> 
> "points that are enclosed by at least two =
neighbors on opposite sides (e.g. left and right) with di=0Bfferent CPPN ac=
tivation levels"
> 
> Note that the points in the outer black region do not=
 have _two_ neighbors of different level on opposite sides, so I believe th=
at is the reason they are pruned away.  However, it's possible that I'm mis=
understanding the question, in which case please let me know.
> 
> Regardin=
g the quote that says, "the CPPN speaks a language through its pattern," th=
is idea conveys that of course there is more than one way to interpret the =
patterns output by CPPNs for this purpose, and any such method of interpret=
ation is a kind of language.  In other words, there might be other perfectl=
y legitimate ways of deciding which connections to express from an infinite=
-resolution pattern that are different from the method in the paper (i.e. t=
hose would be different "languages" for the CPPN to express what it wants).=
  
> 
> However, the "language" suggested in the paper is nice in the sense=
 that it allows the CPPN to express one type of connection without being fo=
rced to express another at the same time - that's what the band pruning ach=
ieves.  Otherwise you'd get points chosen on both sides of a sharp border, =
forcing connections often to be chosen in pairs (which seems an undesirable=
 tendency).
> 
> ken
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "wilsontg80" <wil=
sontg@> wrote:
> >
> > I am puzzled by the result of band pruning in Figure=
 3: Example point selection in two dimensions, from Evolving the Placement =
and Density of Neurons in the HyperNEAT Substrate.  It seems like the infor=
mation inherent in the image should include points along the black-white ed=
ge of the outer black region, but band pruning removes them all.  The figur=
e explains "In effect, the CPPN speaks a language through its pattern that =
denotes exactly which weights within the hypercube should be expressed."  I=
 am curious why "language" is used here.  
> > 
> > My goal is to add itera=
ted ES-HyperNEAT to the C++ version at https://github.com/MisterTea/HyperNE=
AT.  I am presently a hobbyist (my profession is embedded software engineer=
ing) but considering to someday pursue a PhD involving HyperNEAT, etc.
> > =

> > Thanks,
> > Tony Wilson
> >
>
